# Task

Write a function `wrap_string`. It iterates over words and it will add a new line each time a maximum `text_width::Int=10` would be exceeded. Provide an example



# Data

wrap_string("This function will wrap words into lines")

Here is my solution for the problem:
```julia
function wrap_string(str, text_width=10)
    # Split str into individual words using Regex splitter
    words = split(str, r"(?<=[^\s])(?=\s)|(?<=\s)(?=[^\s])")
    lines = []  # List to store the wrapped lines
    current_line = ""  # String to store each line during iteration

    for word in words
        if length(current_line) + length(word) > text_width
            push!(lines, current_line * "\n")  # Add a new line with the current line
            current_line = word * " "  # Reset the current line to store the new word
        else
            current_line *= word * " "
        end
    end

    if !isempty(current_line)
        push!(lines, current_line)  # Add any leftover text on a new line
    end

    return join(lines)  # Return the final wrapped string with new lines
end

# Example usage:
str = "This function will wrap words into lines"
print(wrap_string(str))
```
The `split` function is used to split the input string into individual words using Regex. The function then iterates over each word and checks if adding it to the current line would exceed the maximum text width. If yes, a new line is added, otherwise, the word is added to the current line.
